BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in winter sport activities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the extensive wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. Numerous natural avalanches are to be expected, even very large ones. Single winter sport participants can release avalanches very easily.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size substantially. Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in all aspects.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, further wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions. Fresh and older wind slabs require caution. The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In particular in regions of the north exposed to the foehn wind and at high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more widespread.
The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase as the day progresses. The soft wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant on north, east and south facing slopes above approximately 1900 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible.
In areas close to the tree line a precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions. Wind slabs are to be avoided. Defensive route selection is appropriate.

On very steep slopes small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of the strong northeasterly wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 70 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Since Wednesday on wind-loaded slopes small and medium-sized avalanches were released. On Friday on very steep slopes several medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches occurred naturally.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh and older wind slabs require caution. The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Sunday The northeasterly wind will transport the snow. The soft wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant on north, east and south facing slopes above approximately 2000 m. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here.
In areas close to the tree line a precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some regions. In these regions and at high altitude the avalanche prone locations are more widespread. Meticulous route selection is appropriate.

On very steep slopes individual small to medium-sized natural avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 60 cm of snow, but less in some localities, has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. On Friday on very steep slopes several small and medium-sized avalanches occurred naturally.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. Below approximately 1800 m thus far only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Little snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: On Sunday the wind will be moderate to strong. Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since yesterday the wind has been moderate to strong. In gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
Fresh wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant.
Medium-sized and large dry avalanches are to be expected.
The fresh snow of the last two days as well as the deep wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow has fallen since Monday. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of the northerly wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
The fresh snow of Friday as well as the wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant,. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell on Friday above approximately 1500 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. The new snow can be released naturally in particular on steep shady slopes above approximately 2200 m. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow can be released easily. The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow fell in the last two days above approximately 1900 m. Over a wide area up to 10 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes. Over a wide area new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. Gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 1700 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. Numerous avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Little snow will fall in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 500 m snow fell on Friday. Above approximately 1100 m snow will fall from midday in some localities.
The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
Small and medium-sized dry avalanches are possible. New snow and wind slabs can in some cases be released, in particular by large loads.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 25 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday. In isolated cases new snow is lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At elevated altitudes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects. Numerous avalanches are possible, even very large ones in isolated cases. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area wind and new snow. As a consequence of new snow and wind, wind slabs will form. The wind slabs will form in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution. The fresh wind slabs can be released easily.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of new snow and a strengthening wind, easily released wind slabs will form in particular above the tree line. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Saturday: Over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1000 m. Sunday: In the north over a wide area 10 to 20 cm of snow will fall in all altitude zones. Some snow will fall in the south. The wind will be moderate in some regions. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers. They can be released easily.

The new snow is lying on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh wind slabs remain prone to triggering.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last two days above approximately 1700 m. Over a wide area up to 20 cm of snow will fall on Sunday. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. Gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 1700 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Down to 1000 m snow has fallen over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Over a wide area some new snow to above approximately 1000 m. Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.
In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Some snow has fallen since Friday. Over a wide area thus far only a little snow is lying.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. Backcountry touring calls for caution and restraint.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sometimes strong wind will transport the snow.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to low altitudes snow fell on Friday.
In some localities mostly small wind slabs formed. They are barely recognisable. The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects.

The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, in particular on very steep slopes.
There is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 25 cm of snow has fallen since Wednesday above approximately 2000 m. The sometimes moderate wind has transported only a little snow.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface has a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The avalanche danger will increase but remain within the current danger level.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a moderate wind, mostly small wind slabs will form above the tree line. These can be released in isolated cases. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The avalanche prone locations are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) and at elevated altitudes the avalanche danger is a little higher.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Saturday: 10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1000 m. The wind will be moderate in some regions. Fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow will be deposited on a quite favourable old snowpack in all aspects.
As the snowfall level drops the avalanche prone locations will become more prevalent as the day progresses.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small small avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Bonded new snow above approximately 1500 m.
